required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Evaluation of Tissue Glue on PICC and Midline Catheters Insertion Sites
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of a Tissue Glue SecurePortIV on Prevention of Phlebitis and Migration of PICC and Midline Catheters in Adult Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The study will evaluate a new type of cyanoacrylate tissue glue Secure PortIV on the insertion site of the PICC (Peripherally inserted central catheter) or Midline catheters. Fixation of the catheter with the tissue glue should prevent incidents of mechanical and infective phlebitis as well as external migrations of the catheters.

detailed_description.textblock:
In the study, 125 subjects will receive the new tissue glue Secure PortIV and 125 subjects will be provided standard care. The tissue glue will be applied immediately after insertion. Evaluation and re-evaluation of the site will be done on the first and seventh day after insertion using VIP and CLISA (Central-Line Insertion Site Assessment) scale and on the seventh day with taking a swab from the insertion site; the external length will be measured on the first and the seventh day, in order to observe the migration or not.
The goal of the study is to evaluate the benefits of the cyanoacrylate tissue glue Secure PortIV in the prevention of mechanical and infective phlebitis and external migration of the catheter.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The patients will be enrolled into one of two study groups, depending on the decision of the attending physician.
study_design_info.masking_description: No masking will be used in the study.

primary_outcome.measure: The incidence of mechanical and infective phlebitis
primary_outcome.description: The incidence of mechanical and infective phlebitis will be measured in the group with the cyanoacrylate tissue glue in comparison with the standard treatment

secondary_outcome.measure: The incidence of external migration of the catheter
secondary_outcome.description: The incidence of external migration of the catheter will be measured in the group with the cyanoacrylate tissue glue in comparison with the standard treatment

clinical_study.condition: Adult Patients With Mid-term or Long-term Venous Access

arm_group.arm_group_label: Standard care - catheter fixation with surgical stitch
arm_group.description: In patients indicated for this type of treatment, as per the attending physician, the catheter will be fixed in the standard way, using a surgical stitch.
In patients indicated for this type of treatment, as per the attending physician, the catheter will be fixed using the glue.

intervention.description: The catheter will be fixed using the standard procedure - surgical stitch.
intervention.arm_group_label: Standard care - catheter fixation with surgical stitch

intervention.intervention_name: Catheter fixation with glue (cyanoacrylate tissue glue Secure PortIV)
intervention.description: The catheter will be fixed using the experimental procedure - novel surgical glue.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 years of age
- need of long-term venous access
- consent with participation in the study
Exclusion Criteria:
- pediatric population
- not signing the informed consent form

reference.citation: Scoppettuolo G, Dolcetti L, Emoli A, La Greca A, Biasucci DG, Pittiruti M. Further benefits of cyanoacrylate glue for central venous catheterisation. Anaesthesia. 2015 Jun;70(6):758. doi: 10.1111/anae.13105.

Igarashi A, Okuno T, Shimizu T, Ohta G, Ohshima Y. Mechanical stimulation is a risk factor for phlebitis associated with peripherally inserted central venous catheter in neonates. Pediatr Int. 2021 May;63(5):561-564. doi: 10.1111/ped.14476. Epub 2021 May 7.
Walshe LJ, Malak SF, Eagan J, Sepkowitz KA. Complication rates among cancer patients with peripherally inserted central catheters. J Clin Oncol. 2002 Aug 1;20(15):3276-81.

Pinelli F, Balsorano P, Mura B, Pittiruti M. Reconsidering the GAVeCeLT Consensus on catheter-related thrombosis, 13 years later. J Vasc Access. 2021 Jul;22(4):501-508. doi: 10.1177/1129729820947594. Epub 2020 Aug 8.

patient_data.ipd_description: There is no plan to make individual participant data available to other researchers.
